channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Life Under the Specter of War: Images From Ukraine
item.description: With Russian forces menacing from three sides, Ukrainians are stoically keeping to their daily routines, but reminders of the looming threat are getting hard to avoid.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Hoffman, Tyler Hicks and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Heavy fighting has destroyed beach homes in Shyrokyne, Ukraine, on the Sea of Azov.

item.title: Europe Calls for Peace, but Not at Any Price
item.description: Two days of intense diplomacy on both sides of the Atlantic leave the standoff over Ukraine with Russia frozen in place.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: President Andrzej Duda of Poland, Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany, and President Emmanuel Macron of France in Berlin on Tuesday.

item.title: With No End in Sight, Ottawa Protests Extend Beyond Canada’s Borders
item.description: Officials are grappling with a new protest blocking a major border crossing, while similar demonstrations have disrupted traffic in New Zealand and Australia.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky, Ian Austen and Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Demonstrators in front of Parliament Hill as truckers and their supporters continued to protest against vaccine mandates on Tuesday in Ottawa.

item.title: Photographer’s Death Casts Harsh Light on the Cold Streets of Paris
item.description: René Robert, known for his pictures of flamenco, died of hypothermia after falling on a busy road, seemingly unassisted. The death shocked many, but echoed the indifference homeless people face every day.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden

item.title: Violence Erupts at Syrian Camp for ISIS Families, Leaving a Child Dead
item.description: Security forces say they opened fire this week after they were attacked by women and children at Al Hol camp in northeastern Syria, which holds about 60,000 family members of former ISIS fighters.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Women and children make up the majority of the population at Al Hol detention camp in the Kurdish-led breakaway region of northeastern Syria.

item.title: In Taiwan, When You Hear Beethoven, It’s Time to Take Out the Trash
item.description: Across Taiwan, the classical melody “Für Elise” is a Pavlovian call to action: Bring down your garbage and catch up on neighborhood gossip.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents converging on a garbage truck during the daily trash collection in Taipei, when the city’s streets can sometimes resemble a block party.

item.title: Retired Pope Benedict Asks Forgiveness Over Handling of Abuse Cases
item.description: But Benedict, responding to a report that accused him of mishandling at least four cases of sexual abuse by priests when he was an archbishop in Germany, denied any wrongdoing.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani and Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Emeritus Benedict XVI at the Vatican in 2015.

item.title: Putin Is Operating on His Own Timetable, and It May Be a Long One
item.description: The standoff between Russia and the West over Ukraine could turn into a drawn-out and dangerous diplomatic slog toward a difficult settlement.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier on the front in southern Ukraine. It is likely that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia will seek to keep tensions high for the foreseeable future.

item.title: Inside Denmark’s ‘Live With Covid’ Approach
item.description: The Nordic country is trying a bold, some say risky, approach: with high vaccination rates and trust in the authorities, it has lifted all restrictions.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:credit: Charlotte de la Fuente for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nightclubs in Denmark are reopening, and the government no longer considers Covid a “socially critical disease.”

item.title: Iceland Plane Crash Kills 4 People, Including Celebrated Aviator
item.description: Josh Neuman, 22, an American skateboarder, and Haraldur Diego, 50, an Icelandic pilot, were among those said to have died in the crash of a small aircraft.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: Search and rescue teams found a single-engine plane and the remains of four people in Lake Thingvallavatn over the weekend.

item.title: As Officials Look Away, Hate Speech in India Nears Dangerous Levels
item.description: Activists and analysts say calls for anti-Muslim violence — even genocide — are moving from the fringes to the mainstream, while political leaders keep silent.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Suhasini Raj and Hari Kumar
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Swami Amritanand, an organizer of the event in Haridwar where monks called for violence, defended Mr. Narsinghanand: “He said nothing wrong.”

item.title: What Are the Minsk Accords, and Could They Defuse the Ukraine Crisis?
item.description: European diplomats are exploring whether a seven-year-old negotiating channel, initially intended to resolve a conflict in eastern Ukraine, can be repurposed to calm a wider crisis.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: On the front lines in Donetsk Oblast, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: North Korea Builds ICBM Base Near China to Deter U.S.
item.description: The location is meant to protect its most powerful weapons from pre-emptive strikes, allowing the military to expand an already rapidly growing arsenal.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An image from North Korean state media of a missile test conducted in January at an undisclosed location.

item.title: ‘A Sense of Crisis’ for Wasabi, a Pungent Staple of Japanese Cuisine
item.description: Climate and demographic threats are chipping away at a centuries-old culture surrounding the cultivation of the fluorescent green plant.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich, Makiko Inoue and Shiho Fukada
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mitsuyasu Asada, a third-generation farmer in Shizuoka Prefecture, is concerned that climate change is threatening the future of wasabi.

item.title: How to Watch Nathan Chen Chase Gold in Men’s Figure Skating
item.description: If Chen can maintain his lead in the free skate, he’ll win an Olympic gold medal. His rival, Yuzuru Hanyu of Japan, is looking for a comeback.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Nathan Chen during his short program on Tuesday in Beijing.

item.title: State by State, Germany Relaxes Covid Rules, Even as Cases Surge
item.description: Though case numbers are at a record level, Germany is recording relatively few Covid deaths and stable hospitalization rates.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: A department store in Berlin last year. Several German states are loosening Covid restrictions even as the country’s caseload rises.

item.title: China and Russia's 'Alliance of Autocracies'
item.description: China and Russia have formed an “alliance of autocracies.”
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Vladimir Putin and Xi Jinping in Beijing last week.

item.title: Tonga Extends Its Lockdown as Covid Cases Rise
item.description: The island nation barely saw the coronavirus in the first two years of the pandemic. But after a volcanic eruption, an outbreak among visiting aid workers has pushed up its caseload.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Cpl Robert Whitmore/Australian Defence Force, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Aid workers from Australia assessed damage last week in Tonga, which was hit by a volcanic eruption and tsunami last month.

item.title: Covid Cases Spike in Asia After Lunar New Year Celebrations
item.description: A spike in cases across Asia has followed this month’s holiday.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: A medical worker giving instructions for coronavirus tests in Seoul on Tuesday.

item.title: How the ‘Garlic Girls’ Overcame Abuse to Return to the Olympics
item.description: The South Korean curling team helped revive a painful discussion about the mistreatment of athletes in their country, leading the way for others to come forward.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: South Korea’s women’s curling team — Kim Eun-jung, Kim Kyeong-ae, Kim Seon-yeong, Kim Yeong-mi and Kim Cho-hi — with their silver medals during the 2018 Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Stern warnings from Europe to Russia.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: President Andrzej Duda of Poland, Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany, and President Emmanuel Macron of France in Berlin on Tuesday.

item.title: Vaccine Policy in Los Angeles County Aims to Pressure Sheriff
item.description: The move will apply pressure to the sheriff’s department, which has a vaccination rate of 54 percent.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah
item.media:credit: Allison Zaucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: People registering to get vaccinated at a Los Angeles County’s vaccination site in Los Angeles, California, last month.

item.title: Greta Ferusic Dies at 97; Survived Auschwitz and Siege of Sarajevo
item.description: She was the only one in her family to survive the Holocaust, then endured the shelling of her city during the Bosnian war. A documentary chronicled her story.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Greta Ferusic in 2000. A 1997 film, “Greta,” chronicled her experience of the Holocaust and then the siege of Sarajevo.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Russia Undercuts Macron
item.description: The Kremlin rejected reports of commitments.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France, right, with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine in Kyiv on Tuesday.

item.title: Denmark is overflowing with virus cases, but the population is partying.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:credit: Charlotte de la Fuente for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emilia Silberg, 19, dancing in Copenhagen on Saturday, when Denmark’s nightclubs reopened.

item.title: Backlog at England's Hospitals Will Last Years, Javid Warns
item.description: Sajid Javid, Britain’s health secretary, said that more than 300,000 people in England had been waiting a year or longer for planned medical procedures.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for the New York Times
item.media:description: Medical workers at Homerton Hospital in East London. Surges of coronavirus patients have strained hospitals across Britain, crowding out patients with less immediate needs.

item.title: Boris Johnson Shuffles Team to Tamp Down Mutiny Within His Party
item.description: The British prime minister shuffles his team to tamp down a growing mutiny within his Conservative Party over his leadership.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain outside 10 Downing Street in London last week.

item.title: What is 'Finlandization,' a Status Proposed for Ukraine?
item.description: During the Cold War, Finland promised not to join NATO and let Moscow influence its affairs — the kinds of concessions Ukraine is resisting.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: The Parliament House in central Helsinki. Since signing a treaty with Moscow in 1948, Finland has had to learn how to survive as a small nation in the shadow of a global power.

item.title: Cyclone Batsirai Leaves Devastation and Death in Madagascar
item.description: The island nation was still reeling from the effects of Tropical Storm Ana when the new storm struck, killing more than 20 people and displacing thousands.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: An aerial view shows damaged houses and debris on the beach, in the aftermath of Cyclone Batsirai, in Mananjary, Madagascar, on Tuesday.

item.title: Some Critics Call for Trudeau to Channel His Father on Protests
item.description: The prime minister’s father, Pierre Elliot Trudeau, confronted a violent movement in Quebec in 1970, and his response is “burned” into the memories of many Canadians.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Bob Olsen/Toronto Star, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Troops marching through Montreal on Oct. 20, 1970.

item.title: A Timeline of the Canada Truck Driver's Protest
item.description: After protests over vaccine mandates engulfed Canada’s capital, the mayor of Ottawa declared a state of emergency on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Ottawa on Jan. 29.

item.title: E.U. Cuts Payments to Poland in Dispute Over Unpaid Fines
item.description: For the first time, the E.U. executive arm said it would divert millions in grants to a member country to cover unpaid fines, escalating a confrontation despite jitters over Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:description: A Warsaw street in January. Poland is the largest recipient of E.U. funds, which have been used to modernize the country, financing everything from infrastructure to farm subsidies and scientific research.

item.title: As protest paralyzes Canada’s capital, far-right activists abroad embrace it.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter, Ian Austen and Sheera Frenkel
item.media:credit: Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York Times
item.media:description: The message at the heart of the protests in Canada — that government has been overreaching for too long — has resonated far beyond the country’s borders.

item.title: Macron meets Zelensky in Ukraine, as Russia keeps the world guessing.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives, Ivan Nechepurenko, Michael Schwirtz, Roger Cohen and Shashank Bengali
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, left, welcomes President Emmanuel Macron of France in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: Why the Mask Mandate Debate Is Picking Up Again in the U.S.
item.description: More Democratic governors are saying that masks can come off in schools.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Tomas Ovalle for The New York Times
item.media:description: Elementary school students in Fresno, Calif.

item.title: ‘Fight Club’ Ending Is Restored in China After Censorship Outcry
item.description: Last month, viewers noticed that the ending of the 1999 film had been replaced with a pro-government message. Now the ending is back, and the message is gone.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and John Liu
item.media:description: Brad Pitt in a scene from “Fight Club,” released in 1999.

item.title: The Omicron variant has infected deer in New York City.
item.description: Deer on Staten Island are the first wild animals to have tested positive for the Covid variant. Some experts fear that deer could become a reservoir for the disease and infect humans.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes and Sabrina Imbler
item.media:credit: Sergio Flores for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Sarah Hamer, a veterinary ecologist, and her research team have been studying the effects of Covid-19 on animals and how it could prolong the pandemic.

item.title: Australian Lawmakers Apologize for Sexual Harassment in Parliament
item.description: The move by the prime minister and others acknowledged calls for change after an account of rape inside the defense minister’s office.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Prime Minister Scott Morrison of Australia formally apologizing for harassment in the parliamentary workplace in Canberra on Tuesday.

item.title: Hong Kong Toughens Covid Rules as Omicron Cases Surge
item.description: Among the new restrictions, public gatherings will be limited to two people as the city faces its largest virus outbreak so far.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy and Rebecca Robbins
item.media:description: Waiting at a makeshift Covid-19 testing center in Hong Kong on Tuesday.

item.title: Several States Start Rolling Back Mask Mandates as Infections Fall
item.description: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York is ending the requirement that businesses check for proof of vaccination and enforce mask-wearing.
item.dc:creator: Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Azi Paybarah
item.media:description: At Christa McAuliffe School in Jersey City last year. Starting next month, New Jersey will no longer require students and school employees to wear masks.

item.title: Dog-Sledding in Southern Maine's Winter Wonderland
item.description: Traversing a frozen lake with a team of dogs is an escapist dream in the winter wonderland of Southern Maine. Just remember the brake — and no Instagram selfies.
item.dc:creator: Nina Burleigh
item.media:credit: Erik Freeland for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dog-sledding across the snowy white canvas of Lake Umbagog in Southern Maine.

item.title: Why This Could Be a Critical Year for Electric Cars
item.description: Booming in a depressed market, battery-powered vehicles are a plus for the climate but pose a big threat to carmakers and parts suppliers that are slow to change.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing and Neal E. Boudette
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ford 2022 F-150 Lightning pickup truck, a battery-powered version of the popular F-150, in production at the company’s plant in Dearborn, Mich.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Diplomatic efforts between the West and Russia.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden met the German chancellor, Olaf Scholz, in the East Room at the White House on Monday.

item.title: New York Deer Infected With Omicron, Study Finds
item.description: White-tailed deer on Staten Island have become the first wild animals with documented Omicron infections. The coronavirus has now been found in deer in 15 states.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes and Sabrina Imbler
item.media:credit: Andrew Seng for The New York Times
item.media:description: Research suggests that deer are getting the virus from humans and then spreading it to other deer, and there is no evidence yet that they are spreading it back to people.

item.title: Putin Warns the West and Ukraine, but Keeps His Intentions a Mystery
item.description: President Vladimir Putin said diplomatic ideas raised in a meeting by French President Emmanuel Macron were worth pursuing, but did not rule out a Russian invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Roger Cohen and Katie Rogers
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France arriving for a news conference after talks on Monday with President Vladimir Putin of Russia.

item.title: Ottawa Protests Become Rallying Cry for Far-Right and Anti-Vaccine Groups
item.description: It may be only a few hundred demonstrators occupying Ottawa’s streets to protest government overreach, but their message has aroused passions around the world.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter, Ian Austen and Sheera Frenkel
item.media:credit: Justin Tang/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A truck parked in downtown Ottawa on Monday.

item.title: Canada Convoy Draws Online Support From Far-Right Activists
item.description: Prominent figures in numerous countries, including the U.S., Australia and Germany, have praised the protests, spreading the images and arguments widely.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel
item.media:description: A truck driver looks out from his truck covered in support messages in Ottawa, on Monday.

item.title: A Moment for Canada’s Far Right, Still Struggling for Support
item.description: The country’s political system has made it hard for fringe groups to gain influence. But a new cause, and fund-raising across borders, could begin to fuel Canadian populists.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:credit: Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York Times
item.media:description: The protests have paralyzed downtown Ottawa for 11 days.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Putin and Macron Meet
item.description: The French president said Europe was at a “crossroads.”
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: Russian President Vladimir Putin (L) and French President Emmanuel Macron (R) meet in the Kremlin in Moscow.

item.title: Camilla Queen Consort Title Would Cap Years of Image Repair
item.description: Queen Elizabeth II has put to rest decades of speculation by giving Prince Charles’ wife, Camilla, what some see as her “stamp of approval.”
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Saskia Solomon
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall, in September.

item.title: ‘I Have to Come Back Home’: In the Trenches With Ukraine’s Soldiers
item.description: We spent the day with Ukrainian soldiers on the front lines of the conflict with Russia-backed separatists near the southeast border with Russia.
item.dc:creator: Brent McDonald, Yousur Al-Hlou, Andriy Dubchak and Dmitriy Khavin

item.title: Israel to Investigate Domestic Use of Pegasus Spyware as Scrutiny Hits Home
item.description: The decision reflected rising concerns about the use of the spyware in Israel, and could affect the corruption trial of former Prime Minister Netanyahu.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: The entrance to an NSO Group branch in Sapir, Israel.

item.title: BA.2 Omicron Subvariant Gains In Europe, But May Not Change Much
item.description: Though the BA.2 subvariant spreads more readily, it does not appear to cause more serious disease than the BA.1 version of Omicron, the coronavirus variant that drove the latest global surge.
item.dc:creator: Ron DePasquale
item.media:credit: Charlotte de la Fuente for The New York Times
item.media:description: Denmark is ending pandemic restrictions even though an even more contagious version of the Omicron variant has become dominant in the country.

item.title: Marc Overmars, Dutch Soccer Star, Quits Post After Admitting to Inappropriate Texts
item.description: Marc Overmars, a former player who became a director at Ajax, one of Europe’s top clubs, apologized for his actions. The club said he had “gone over the line.”
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Marc Overmars at Ajax’s stadium in Amsterdam last May.

item.title: Who Are the Protesters and What Do They Want?
item.description: The demonstrators are a diverse collection of people animated by fatigue over pandemic restrictions, seeking something that is not in the federal government’s power to grant.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: Protesters in Toronto on Saturday.

item.title: Syria’s Kurds Wanted Autonomy. They Got an Endless War.
item.description: The Kurds of northeastern Syria dreamed of establishing an autonomous, multiethnic and gender-equal utopia. Instead, their breakaway region has been engulfed in conflict since its creation.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thousands attended the burial of 12 fighters from the Kurdish-led forces who were killed while battling Islamic State militants who took over a prison.

item.title: Macron meets Putin in Moscow, aiming for a de-escalation.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen, Ivan Nechepurenko, Aurelien Breeden, Shashank Bengali and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia meeting with his French counterpart Emmanuel Macron in Moscow on Monday.
